summary: feline calicivirus (FCV) and feline herpesvirus type 1 (FHV-1) have worldwide distribution. the virus is a virus that belongs to the Vesivirus genus and the Caliciviridae family. it has a small, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome. more than 90% of the cats are seropositive to FHV. 45% remain latently infected with 45% shedding the virus by all life long. vaccine does not appear to be protective (4). prevalence of FCV has varied from 15% to 31% (2, 12, 16) whereas values ranging from less than 1% to 63% have been estimated for the prevalence of FHV-1 (2, 13, 15) these viruses are still prevalent in the feline population despite the fact that vaccination against FCV and FHV-1 has been practiced since the 1970s. the samples were collected from 302 cats from veterinary clinics and hospitals, residences, breeding catteries and experimental populations. the samples were collected from animals in the following counties of the Rio Grande do Sul State, Brazil. cultures exhibiting CPE were investigated for presence of feline calicivirus (FCV), feline herpesvirus type 1 (FHV-1) or both viruses using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay. three blind passages were performed for cultures not exhibiting CPE. the cDNA was used as a template for the PCR for FCV identification. the primer sequences were 8F (forward) 5' -
